awd_titl_txt: EPRI: Collaborative Research: Hydrogen Production via Electrochemical Reforming of Ethanol in a Proton Exchange Membrane Cell
awd_abstract_narration:
Production of hydrogen from biomass and/or biofuels has been proposed as an interim method between the current hydrogen production from fossil fuels, such as methane and coal, and hydrogen production using renewable sources (e.g., solar and wind).  This project aims to develop a highly energy-efficient process for hydrogen production in a proton exchange membrane (PEM) cell via the ethanol electrochemical reforming reaction (EER).  Ethanol is an attractive feedstock for hydrogen production because of the existing infrastructure for its large-scale production from biomass. The proposed work will investigate the use of partially oxidized noble metal catalysts as a new group of anode catalysts enabling fast reaction kinetics (rapid charge transfer) and high efficiency.

The production of hydrogen by the EER process will be studied in a PEM cell, where the hydrogen evolution reaction happens at the cathode and the rate-limiting ethanol oxidation reaction happens at the anode.  The hypotheses are: (1) Lattice oxygen from partially oxidized noble metals (MOx) will be more active to remove poisoning species than adsorbed OH (the dissociative product of water acting as a common oxidant in electro-catalysis); (2) The ensemble effect, associated with particular arrangements of the noble metal (M) and O constituents, may play an important role towards the C-C splitting of ethanol.  The hypotheses will be tested by a combination of theoretical and experimental investigations: Density  functional theory (DFT) calculations will be performed to study the stability and reactivity towards C-C splitting on partially oxidized noble metals (MOx, M: Pt, Rh, Ir, Pd and Ru) in slab and nanoparticle forms. Solution phase synthesis of MOx clusters, predicted by DFT calculations to have high effectiveness for complete oxidation of ethanol, will be performed. Structural characterization of the clusters will be performed using a variety of techniques, including aberration-corrected scanning transmission electronic microscopy and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) at National Laboratories.  EER kinetics will be evaluated in both half-cells and single-cells, from which energy efficiency, hydrogen and carbon dioxide generation rates, and selectivity will be calculated and used to evaluate the performance of the proposed MOx catalysts.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The major research objectives of the proposed project are to develop, through theoretical and experimental efforts, a highly energy-efficient process for hydrogen production via the ethanol electrochemical reforming via reacting ethanol and water to form hydrogen and carbon dioxide using partially oxidized noble metal catalysts as the catalysts. Results obtained from density functional theory calculations, materials synthesis and characterization, and electrochemical analyses will help develop a new genre of partially oxidized noble metal catalysts with high reactivity and selectivity for the complete oxidation of ethanol at the anode (the bottleneck of the proposed electrochemical reforming process).  The educational objectives of the project are to (i) train graduate and undergraduate students through studying the electrochemical process for energy conversion, (ii) incorporate the research outcomes in undergrad education curriculum, and (iii) develop learning materials for STEM education through training and educating high school science teachers during summer research.

The main outcomes of the proposed project include:

(i) The PI has successfully synthesized carbon-supported noble metal nanocatalysts (e.g., Rh, Pt, Ir, and Pd) nanoparticles with well-controlled sizes ranging from 1.9 nm to 8.4 nm and the controlled surface oxygen coverage.   

(ii) The PI has successfully demonstrated that noble metal catalysts could facilitate ethanol conversion via complete C-C bond splitting at room temperature.  While various noble metal catalysts showed the C-C cleavage capabilities, Rh nanoclusters demonstrate the best activity and selectivity toward C-C bond splitting than other materials in the following order: Rh > Pt > Ir > Au > Ag.  The outcome of the Rh on ethanol conversion via C-C bond splitting was published in 2019 (J. Am. Chem. Soc, 2019, 141, 9444-9447).

(iii) Using isotope labeling mass spectrometry, the PI has successfully demonstrated that lattice oxygen on the surface of the noble metal clusters was much more active toward complete oxidation of reaction intermediates, originated from C-C bond splitting from the ethanol to carbon dioxide. Our results underscore the highly selective role of lattice oxygen toward ethanol conversion and will provide a good routine for utilizing ethanol as a feedstock for producing valuable chemicals in environmentally benign conditions.  

(iv) The PI has successfully hosted two high-school science teachers for Research Experiences for Teachers in Engineering (RETE) program in 2018 and 2021. 

 


Last Modified: 08/26/2021
Modified by: Xiaowei Teng
